{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3160410,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-08T23:48:49.799Z","cooked":"

So I have these 5v addressable RGB ws2812B string lights and I’m trying to get them to light up. i have the vrm plugged into the switchable channel on the rev PDH. This is the wiring setup:

IMG_20230308_1838034671920×1440 212 KB

I plugged in the green wire to pwm port 1 and plugged the white and red wires that aren’t connected to the green wire onto the 5v 2a port on the vrm.

One thing I noticed was that the lights on the vrm weren’t on, is the switchable channel turned off by default?

Did I wire the LEDs correctly?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-03-08T23:48:49.799Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":113,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":620.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":429468,"topic_slug":"addressable-led-wiring-problem","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/7/d/7d3d72854aa92c2f6a91cf2304ecd0374bf3cae9.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/addressable-led-wiring-problem/429468/1","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3160413,"name":"Lizzie Clare","username":"lizziec113","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lizziec113/{size}/214930_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-08T23:52:10.139Z","cooked":"

Are you using all of the other low current ports? The VRM is not supposed to be plugged into the switchable port. If you move it to one if the other low current ports (or even a high current port with the smallest breaker you have), it should work fine.

Yes all the other low current channels are in use. If I use a 10amp breaker in a high current channels would that work better?

Thanks!! What about my led wiring. Are those wires going to be plugged into the right spots? The green wire goes straight to the rio pwm port and the separate red and white wires go the vrm.

Is that possible? How much current can those draw?

You’d have to look at the specs for whatever LED strip you have.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T01:04:08.404Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":36.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":429468,"topic_slug":"addressable-led-wiring-problem","display_username":"Nathan Shepherd","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49423,"username":"Gandagorn","name":"Elliot Scher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M"},"post_url":"/t/addressable-led-wiring-problem/429468/8","custom_user_title":"2079 A -> 246 M -> 1153/1119 M","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3160460,"name":"Nate","username":"ns3517","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ns3517/{size}/8364_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T01:10:52.621Z","cooked":"

Look at the specs, it should have a power draw per led. Then count how many are going on your robot and see if it is near the max draw on the roborio.

The robo rio dio rail can produce a max of 2.2 amps. If its a small strip that uses under 1.5a id use robo rio. If its close to the max current draw, i always lean towards play it safe and power off the vrm or a custom circuit off the pdh. You can build a custom circuit by using a 12v to 5v converter.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T01:11:30.169Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":179,"readers_count":178,"score":40.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":429468,"topic_slug":"addressable-led-wiring-problem","display_username":"Nate","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49423,"username":"Gandagorn","name":"Elliot Scher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25567,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Yeah-Yeah"},"post_url":"/t/addressable-led-wiring-problem/429468/9","custom_user_title":"Yeah-Yeah","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3160469,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T01:22:24.347Z","cooked":"

There’ll be more than the 2.2 amps can handle. Will the way I described above work with the vrm?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T01:22:24.347Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":429468,"topic_slug":"addressable-led-wiring-problem","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25567,"username":"ns3517","name":"Nate","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ns3517/{size}/8364_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/addressable-led-wiring-problem/429468/10","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3160578,"name":"Nate","username":"ns3517","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ns3517/{size}/8364_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T03:46:55.506Z","cooked":"

No, because you mentioned the vrm 5v 2a slot as a power source and you are saying you need more then 2.2a power for the leds.

How many amps are you planning to draw from the leds?

Your best option would probably be a 12v to 5v converter that goes straight into the PDH which will be easily enough power.

Just make sure you check the current cap on your converter. The data sheet will show this.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T04:21:40.976Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":157,"readers_count":156,"score":31.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":429468,"topic_slug":"addressable-led-wiring-problem","display_username":"Nate","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49423,"username":"Gandagorn","name":"Elliot Scher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25567,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Yeah-Yeah"},"post_url":"/t/addressable-led-wiring-problem/429468/14","custom_user_title":"Yeah-Yeah","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3160647,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T06:45:39.857Z","cooked":"
lizziec113:

The VRM is not supposed to be plugged into the switchable port.

This is fine if it’s not powering your radio. In that case it’s just acting as a voltage regulator in a custom circuit.

NShep98:

Is there a reason you’re not just powering the strip off the PWM port?

Do not do this. One, because the Rio PWM ports output 6V on their power pin, not 5V, and it’s likely to cook your LEDs. And two, because it’s not a good idea to put a heavy load on the voltage regulators built into literally the most critical component on the robot, when a cheap 12V-to-5V regulator will give you more current and no risk.

Gandagorn:

There’ll be more than the 2.2 amps can handle.

By spec, WS2812B’s can draw up to 50mA per LED (at full brightness white output). You’ll rarely see that, though. We ran 119 LEDs on a 3A DC-DC converter last year with no issues at all. Safest bet would be to measure what you’re actually drawing, of course.

Peter_Johnson:

If there’s no rule prohibiting it, it’s legal.

Absolutely. This is considered a “custom circuit” and is quite common. Just follow other wiring rules (wire gauge according to fuse size, etc.) and you’ll be good.

bbonner:

This is fine if it’s not powering your radio. In that case it’s just acting as a voltage regulator in a custom circuit.

That’s good to know! We’re using the rev power module to power the radio and the only thing we’re running on the vrm is the LEDs. Is the switchable channel off by default? because when we’ve tried to turn the robot on the vrm lights to not illuminate.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":34,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T11:27:31.126Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":37.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":429468,"topic_slug":"addressable-led-wiring-problem","display_username":"Elliot Scher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49423,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)"},"post_url":"/t/addressable-led-wiring-problem/429468/17","custom_user_title":"2815A (19-23) | 190M (23...)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3160756,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T14:31:25.947Z","cooked":"

Overloading PWM ports could cause that rail (6V) to turn off, disabling all the other PWM outputs. But it won’t brown out the entire Rio (your code will keep running). And if you don’t have anything else on PWMs, losing that rail isn’t a big deal.

Gandagorn:

Is the switchable channel off by default?

I don’t know what the firmware defaults to, but your code should explicitly set it to the state you want at startup. That way there is no question.

Gandagorn:

because when we’ve tried to turn the robot on the vrm lights to not illuminate.

You said above that you needed more than 2.2A, but the VRM is only rated for 2A (peak, 1.5A continuous), so that might be a problem. Although if you are only lighting some of the LEDs, e.g. to test, you should not be anywhere near the current limit.

What are you commanding the LEDs to display? They will not light unless the software sets them to a color.

Are you sure you have the PWM signal pin connected to the “in” end of the strip? LED strips are directional, so if you accidentally connect to the wrong end, the signal will not pass LED-to-LED and it will not work at all.
